extractions.description: This paper discusses the creation and validation of a large-scale, data-driven, biophysically detailed model of the rat primary somatosensory cortex (S1), primarily focused on its non-barrel regions. It addresses the integration of anatomical and physiological data to simulate neural activity, calibrate extrinsic inputs, and validate the model against in vivo data from rodent cortex. The study also includes in silico experimentation to emulate laboratory conditions and provide predictions about cortical processing.

type.justification: The paper presents data-driven modeling, simulations, and validation against experimental data.
type.quote: We characterized which parts of the spectrum are compatible with available experimental data on layer-specific delays and amplitudes of responses to simple stimuli, and found an in vivo-like regime at the edge of a transition from asynchronous to synchronous spontaneous activity.

name.justification: The paper involves computational modeling and simulation of neural microcircuits.
name.quote: We describe here, and in a companion paper, an approach to address the scaling challenges and provide a model of multiple interacting cortical regions at a subcellular level of detail.

name.justification: The study focuses on simulating neural activity and validating the model using experimental data.
name.quote: We developed a rich set of simulation tools to recreate a diverse set of laboratory experiments in silico, providing further validation and demonstrating the utility of the model in a variety of paradigms.

name.justification: The research entails constructing models from vast amounts of experimental data and refining them iteratively.
